entry.title: Re: Which process log to the XI_SEC_MSG table?
entry.content:
Hello, 

This is generally related to the security configurations in the SOAP Adapter (also similar configuration options exist in other channel types). 
"SOAP messages can be secured either by using Web service security (signature only) or S/MIME standards (signature and encryption)." 
If the Security Profile option for either Web Services Security or S/MIME is enabled in the channel (see below screenshot), then these messages are written to the XI_SEC_MSG table. These entries must then be archived. 

Regards
Mark

entry.title: Re: How to use the OData Client Proxy in SAP S/4 HANA or How to use the OData Service Consumption Mo
entry.content:
I have finally managed to create a remote proxy using OData V4.

The key is the proxy factory class.

You will have to use this class /iwbep/cl_cp_client_proxy_fact instead of /iwbep/cl_cp_factory_remote.

@wagener-mark: Have you managed it? What is your problem with 

cl_http_client=>create_by_destination

You just have to use it like this and then call the proxy factory. Either for V2 or V4.

cl_http_client=>create_by_destination( 
    exporting  destination = 'RemoteConnection'
    importing  client      = client ).

Btw.: I've developed the proxy with S4HANA2023 FSP02.

entry.title: API-Based Bank Integration for SAP BCM ‚Äì Seeking Best Practices and Lessons Learned
entry.content:
We are planning to embark on a new project focused on integrating with banks via APIs. Currently, we use pain.001 messages to send payment instructions to the bank and transmit via SFTP and receive pain.002 responses, which we process to update BCM statuses.

For this new approach, we do not intend to use any SAP middleware components such as MBC or the Digital Payments Add-On. Instead, we aim to consume the bank‚Äôs existing APIs directly as there will be no APIs on our side. Also, we would like to continue using the BCM monitor but not sure how this will be updated using APIs. We are still using the S4HANA On-Premise version.

Questions for the Community

  • Has anyone implemented a similar API-based integration with banks?
  • How did you approach the implementation and testing with the bank?
  • Does the bank proactively notify you when they change or update their APIs?
  • How feasible is this scenario compared to traditional file-based integration or when using some middleware?

    Additional Considerations

    • Security: How do you manage authentication (OAuth, certificates, token refresh) and ensure secure data transmission?
    • Error Handling: What strategies do you use for retries, timeouts, and reconciliation if API calls fail or responses are delayed?
    • Monitoring: How do you track API performance and maintain an audit trail for compliance? Do you integrate with SAP BCM monitoring or build a custom dashboard?
    • Version Management: How do you handle API version changes and backward compatibility?
    • Performance: Are there latency issues compared to file-based pain.002 processing?

      Looking forward to your responses.

      Regards,

entry.title: New Expert-Guided Implementation: Joule Prerequisites and Activation
entry.content:
Establish the Foundation for Your AI Journey 

SAP Joule is transforming how organizations interact with SAP applications by bringing intelligence directly into everyday workflows. For customers to activate Joule and unlock its AI-powered capabilities, they must first prepare their SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS), SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and integration foundations to fully realize the value of Joule from day one. 

To support customers with this essential preparation, we are pleased to introduce a new Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI):  

Joule Prerequisites & Activation - a hands-on, expert-led program designed to help you configure all required technical components for a smooth Joule activation. 

This new offering helps customers understand Joule‚Äôs architecture, explore deployment options, configure platform prerequisites, and establish the identity and access foundation required for a secure activation. By the end of the EGI, participants will be positioned to complete all the prerequisites required to activate Joule, ensuring a seamless start to their AI adoption journey. 

Workshop Schedule 

To accommodate global participants, this session will be offered on the following dates and time zones as follows: 

2026 DatesTimeTime Zone 
January 19-2010:00AM - 12:00PMEMEA | CET
January 26-2711:00AM - 1:00PMNA/LA | EST 
February 9-1010:00AM-12:00PMEMEA | CET
February 16-1711:00AM - 1:00PMNA/LA | EST 
March 2-310:00AM-12:00PMEMEA | CET
March 9-1011:00AM - 1:00PMNA/LA | EST 


Why This EGI Matters 

Before Joule can be activated, customers must ensure the right technical prerequisites are in place‚Äîacross SAP BTP, Cloud Identity Services, Build Work Zone, and Line-of-Business systems. This EGI provides: 

  • A clear, step-by-step path to completing these prerequisites 
  • Expert-led guidance for setting up SAP Cloud Identity Services including Identity Authentication Service (IAS)/Identity Provisioning Service (IPS), and entitlements 
  • Live configuration guidance in your SAP BTP environment and SAP Build Workzone (BWZ) 
  • Hands-on support through real examples and troubleshooting 

With AI rapidly becoming central to SAP‚Äôs product strategy, organizations need the right technical foundation to adopt Joule with confidence, security, and scalability. 

What You‚Äôll Learn: Program Overview 

This 2-day EGI blends instruction, demonstrations, and guided hands-on exercises. 

Day 1 ‚Äì Foundation & Architecture 

  • Understand Joule‚Äôs system architecture and deployment scenarios 
  • Learn how SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS/IPS), SAP BTP, SAP Build Work Zone, and LOB solutions work together 
  • Navigate BTP global accounts, subaccounts, entitlements, and subscriptions 
  • Validate system readiness and begin configuring your Joule environment 
  • Experience a live demonstration of Joule integrated with SAP SuccessFactors 

Day 2 ‚Äì Identity, Provisioning & Work Zone Integration 

  • Deep-dive into SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS) and Identity Provisioning (IPS) for Joule 
  • Integrate CIS with your corporate Identity Provider 
  • Configure SAP Build Workzone (BWZ) as the unified interface for Joule 
  • Establish trust relationships between systems 
  • Expose LOB content to BWZ and validate provisioning flows 


What You Will Achieve 

This new EGI equips your organization with everything needed to prepare for Joule activation, ensuring compliance, security, and a streamlined technical foundation from day one. 

If your organization is planning to adopt SAP Joule or preparing for AI-driven innovation within SAP applications, this EGI is the ideal starting point to fast-track your readiness and reduce implementation risk. 

By the end of the EGI, you will have: 

  • A configured SAP BTP environment with a designated Joule subaccount 
  • Completed IAS/IPS setup for secure authentication and provisioning 
  • Integrated BWZ as the experience layer for Joule 
  • Verified all activation prerequisites using a comprehensive readiness checklist 
  • Gained expert-backed confidence to run the Joule Booster and proceed with activation

How to Register 

Register here to secure your spot* today to learn from SAP experts and gain the skills to bring Business AI to life across your enterprise.

 * You may need to register your S-user for access to SAP Learning Hub to access the EGI registration page.  It is a one-time registration, click here.

Related Articles

Unlocking Joule and SAP Business AI from Strategy to Activation: Expert-Guided Implementation

entry.title: Re: How to overwrite the values of Schedule Line's Delive...
entry.content:
Hello please @bigflatfoot  - Please use MV45AFZZ
there are two cases 

INSERT of new line item - while fresh insert of a line XVBEP-updkz will be I  , in this case you dont need YVBEP entry to be update

if you are UPDATING -  an item already created you need to play with xvbep internal table and and make sure YVBEP internal table is also having a entry 

use UE - USEREXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE.
Note - BAPI_AVAILABILITY can also key role here  , if you are updating something before other than this exit it might overwrite be watchful , check in your case by  placing a breakpoint and see the difference
hope this helps !.

Kiran Angar

entry.title: Re: Why SAP S/4HANA Go‚ÄëLives Fail After ‚ÄúSuccess‚Äù: The Hidden Content & Attachment Layer
entry.content:
Hi  

RobertVit

Absolutely agree ‚Äî external archiving is the target state and should be standard.

The problem I‚Äôm highlighting is that even with ArchiveLink or external content servers, migrations still move pointers and metadata, not the physical documents. If repositories, links, or KPro mappings are inconsistent, you end up with ‚Äúarchived‚Äù documents that no longer open, even though they‚Äôre not in HANA.

So the risk isn‚Äôt just where PDFs are stored, but whether the entire content chain (SOFFCONT1 / SRGBTBREL / KPro / ArchiveLink repositories) is validated end‚Äëto‚Äëend during conversion ‚Äî which most projects skip.

External archive is necessary ‚Äî but content validation is the missing gate.

entry.title: String type field length limitation issue when mapping HANA SQL script dataset to an ABAP itab.
entry.content:
Hello experts,

When I'm mapping HANA SQL script dataset to an ABAP itab, there is a length limitation with string type fields.

string_agg(t5.json_data, ' ' order by canum) as json_data "AS NVARCHAR
to_clob(string_agg( t5.json_data,'' order by canum )      "AS CLOB

This function works correctly in the DBeaver query window, successfully returning a string with an actual field value length that exceeds 27,000 characters.

However, this function does not perform as expected when mapping a HANA dataset to an ABAP internal table.

It faces limitations, such as nvarchar being restricted to 5,000 characters and clob to 16,384 characters, resulting in the truncation of the actual field value.

The code is as follows:

types: begin of ty_data_in,
           count           type i,
           enq_lck_arg     type char50,
           tstp            type timestamp,
           itfid           type ze_itfid,
           id              type zfunc_log_id,
           func_name       type zfunc_log_data-func_name,
           func_parameter  type zfunc_log_data-func_parameter,
           func_paramtype  type zfunc_log_data-func_paramtype,
           func_structure  type zfunc_log_data-func_structure,
           func_defaultval type zfunc_log_data-func_defaultval,
           func_type       type zfunc_log_data-func_type,
           func_class      type zfunc_log_data-func_class,
           func_ref_class  type zfunc_log_data-func_ref_class,
           json_data       type string,
           proc            type flag,
         end of ty_data_in. 
  data: lt_data_in     type table of ty_data_in with empty key,
        lt_stmt        type table of string,
        l_stmt         type string.

lt_stmt[] = value #( ( |with | )
				   ( |t2 as (| )
				   ( |select t1.note3 as enq_lck_arg,t1.tzntstmps_beg as tstp,t1.note1 as itfid,t1.id| )
				   ( |  from zfunc_log as t1| )
				   ( |  where t1.note1 { l_zrfcid }| )
				   ( |    and t1.erdat { l_erdat }| )
				   ( |    and t1.code in ('I')| )
				   ( |),| )
				   ( |t3 as (select t2.enq_lck_arg,sum( 1 ) as count from t2 group by t2.enq_lck_arg order by t2.enq_lck_arg),| )
				   ( |t4 as (| )
				   ( |select t2.enq_lck_arg,t2.tstp,t2.itfid,t2.id,t3.count| )
				   ( |  from t2| )
				   ( |  join t3 on t3.enq_lck_arg = t2.enq_lck_arg| )
				   ( |  order by t3.count,t2.enq_lck_arg,t2.tstp,t2.itfid,t2.id| )
				   ( |)| )
				   ( |select t4.count,t4.enq_lck_arg,t4.tstp,t4.itfid,t4.id,| )
				   ( |       t5.func_name,t5.func_parameter,t5.func_paramtype,t5.func_structure,t5.func_defaultval,t5.func_type,t5.func_class,t5.func_ref_class,string_agg( t5.json_data,' ' order by canum ) as json_data| )
				   ( |  from t4| )
				   ( |  join zfunc_log_data as t5 on t5.id = t4.id| )
				   ( |  group by t4.count,t4.enq_lck_arg,t4.tstp,t4.itfid,t4.id,t5.func_name,t5.func_parameter,t5.func_paramtype,t5.func_structure,t5.func_defaultval,t5.func_type,t5.func_class,t5.func_ref_class| )
				   ( |  order by t4.count,t4.enq_lck_arg,t4.tstp,t4.itfid,t4.id,t5.func_name,t5.func_parameter,t5.func_paramtype,t5.func_structure,t5.func_defaultval,t5.func_type,t5.func_class,t5.func_ref_class;| )
				   ).
l_stmt = reduce #( init sum type string for wa in lt_stmt[] next sum = cond #( when sum is initial then wa else |{ sum }{ wa }| ) ). 

perform frm_hana_exec_query tables lt_data_in[] using l_stmt."json_data string type  still got length limit

form frm_hana_exec_query tables pt_data type table
                         using  p_stmt type string.
  data: l_s_dbindex type dbindex,
        l_stmt      type string,
        lref_data   type ref to data,
        lref_stmt   type ref to cl_sql_statement,
        lref_rslt   type ref to cl_sql_result_set.
  field-symbols: <fs_data> type any.

  try.
      assign pt_data[] to <fs_data>.
      l_stmt = p_stmt.

      create object lref_stmt.
      "lref_stmt->set_param( ref #( tabname ) ).
      "lref_stmt->set_param( ref #( l_schema ) ).

      lref_rslt = lref_stmt->execute_query( l_stmt ).
      get reference of <fs_data> into lref_data.
      lref_rslt->set_param_table( lref_data ).
      lref_rslt->next_package( ).
      lref_rslt->close( ).
    catch cx_sql_exception into data(lref_sqlerr).
      free: <fs_data>.
      data(l_msg) = lref_sqlerr->get_longtext( ).
      message |HANA QUERY ERROR: { l_msg }| type 'E'.
  endtry.
endform.

entry.title: Extending SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Build: Building a Global Payroll Dashboard Using ECP Data
entry.content:
üéØThe focus here is purely on how SAP SuccessFactors functionality can be extended using SAP Build and side-by-side extensibility.

The End Goal: A Global Payroll Dashboard Inside the People Profile

 

The screen above represents the final outcome of this journey:
A Global Payroll Dashboard embedded directly into the Latest People Profile, showing payroll headcount insights sourced from ECP.

This dashboard is:

  • Built using SAP Build
  • Deployed on SAP BTP
  • Embedded into SuccessFactors as a side-by-side extension card

No core SuccessFactors customization. No upgrade risk.

Why Side-by-Side Extensibility?

Traditional customizations can slow innovation and complicate upgrades. Side-by-side extensibility offers a smarter approach. 

With side-by-side extensibility:

  • Custom logic runs outside the SuccessFactors core
  • Extensions are built and managed on SAP BTP
  • The core HR system remains clean and upgrade-safe

SAP Build makes this approach accessible by enabling both low-code and pro-code development models‚Äîallowing HR IT teams to move faster without sacrificing governance.

Step 1: Starting in SAP SuccessFactors

The journey begins in SuccessFactors, where administrators:

  • Navigate using global search
  • Access the Latest People Profile configuration
  • Manage profile layout, categories, and extension cards

This ensures that extensions feel native to the SuccessFactors experience.

Step 2: Creating a Side-by-Side Extension with SAP Build

Using the extensibility capabilities in SuccessFactors:

  • A new side-by-side extension is created
  • SAP Build is selected as the development approach
  • An SAP Fiori Card‚Äìbased UI is chosen

This step defines how the extension will later appear inside the People Profile.

Step 3: Designing the Payroll Card in SAP Build

Once the extension is created, development continues in SAP Business Application Studio:

  • Payroll data is consumed from ECP (via preconfigured integrations)
  • Card logic and visualization are defined
  • Live previews help validate the user experience

This is where raw payroll data becomes meaningful insight.

Step 4: Deploying Back to SuccessFactors

 

After development:

  • The SAP Build card is deployed
  • A secure SAP BTP destination is selected
  • The extension becomes available to SuccessFactors

This seamless handoff highlights the power of SAP BTP as an extensibility platform.

Step 5: Embedding the Card in the Latest People Profile

 

 

 

Back in SuccessFactors:

  • A custom Global Payroll Dashboard category is created
  • The SAP Build card is assigned to the category
  • Visibility and order are controlled

The result is a role-based, personalized profile experience.

The Final Experience: Payroll Insights Where Users Work

For end users‚ÄîHR, payroll admins, or managers‚Äîthe experience is simple:

  • Navigate to My Employee File
  • Open the Global Payroll Dashboard
  • View payroll insights directly in context

No additional apps. No context switching.

Key Takeaways

Side-by-side extensibility with SAP Build enables organizations to:

  • Extend SAP SuccessFactors without modifying the core system
  • Transform real ECP payroll data into actionable insights
  • Deliver custom dashboards directly inside the People Profile
  • Innovate faster while remaining upgrade-safe

SAP Build + SAP BTP + SuccessFactors = Clean-core innovation done right.

Final Thoughts

This journey demonstrates that extensibility doesn‚Äôt have to be complex or risky. With SAP Build and side-by-side extensibility, SuccessFactors becomes a platform for continuous innovation‚Äîwhile keeping the core stable and future-ready.

If you‚Äôre exploring ways to bring payroll, finance, or external insights into SuccessFactors, this approach is a powerful pattern worth adopting.

I‚Äôve also created a YouTube video demonstrating this end-to-end scenario using SAP Build and side-by-side extensibility: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_BE5LcVzDxc

In the end, it‚Äôs important to mention that 

This blog does not cover:

  • How to build or expose ECP APIs
  • How to configure SAP BTP destinations
  • How to technically connect SuccessFactors with SAP BTP
  • How SAP BTP integrates with Employee Central or ECP

All backend integrations are assumed to be already in place.

entry.title: Q4 2025 Innovations: SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Welcome to the quarterly innovation highlights for  SAP Enterprise Service Management for Q4 2025.  Here, I want to feature some key capabilities that have been released within the past three months. We invite you to register for our Q4 2025 Innovations webcast for SAP Enterprise Management and Service Cloud on Tuesday, January 27th and SAP Sales Cloud and Foundation on Wednesday, January 28th ensuring you stay up-to-date on all the innovations and improvements delivered in Q4 2025.

Also, Learn more about the latest Q4 2025 innovations across the SAP CX portfolio here.

What‚Äôs New in SAP Enterprise Service Management
 SAP Enterprise Management is unifying internal service delivery operations across the globe. AI is driving measurable results in workplace productivity and stay tuned for an update on the progress of our ESM@SAP initiative ‚Äì with already more than 1200 support agents across more than 10 use cases from learning to finance and people and culture using SAP ESM!  Tight integration with the SAP Cloud ERP applications is driving quick deployments, quick time-to-value and bringing users high satisfaction by delivering a truly unified workspace.

Before we jump into the highlights,  please remember to review Kirsi‚Äôs Q4 2025 release blog for SAP Service Cloud blog which provides additional innovation highlights benefiting SAP Enterprise Service Management as well!

Now, let me introduce you to some Q4 2025 innovations spanning across useability, extensibility, automation and more!

Personalized KPI Cards in Home Page & Cases:

Personalized KPI cards enables business level configuration of real time app data presented in the home page or in cases to ensure support agents and managers have a pulse on performance. Bringing together information from various applications helps to ensure KPI‚Äôs are meaningful and deliver the right insights.

Object-Based Navigation in Mashups

Mashups enable a unified workspace and align various parameters into the business context. However, it is common, especially with custom applications for support agents to work in a separate browser tab.  This navigation enables a quick view to open from custom timeline events in a new browser tab while maintain key parameters.

Navigate to Custom UI‚Äôs from Mashups

Ease of navigation is key for support agents. Ensuring processes can be modeled effectively is critical to not only ensure agent satisfaction but to facilitate quick resolutions. Navigation from mashups is now expanded to custom UI‚Äôs.

Shortcuts in the Shell Bar

Recent items and favorites have been added to the shortcuts in the shell bar.  Service agents can now access a quick list of their favorites with a click in the shell bar reducing navigation steps. Additionally, an agent can easily retrieve complex tasks or activities they have in-work with one click to view the last 15 recent items. They can bypass menus and searches for one-click access to active work items.

Reference field usage in the Case

The ability to use fields from other entities such as employee, supplier or customer in the case is supports context and processing. Enabling these entities as reference fields in the case processes such as autoflow or rules and in defining customer logic helps streamline processes for the support agent and enables deep context ensuring the right data is considered and included in case resolution steps.

Intent-Based Navigation

Embedded analytics drive key insights to user, now with intent-based navigation a user can go from our embedded SAP Analytics Cloud directly to a case or other entity and make updates without having to click through menu navigation. This truly is ‚Äúfrom insights to action,‚Äù in just a click or two. Check out more details and a video on Intent-Based Navigation in my colleague Shameek‚Äôs blog.  

Case Step Pre-Conditions including Business Documents

Business document integration with SAP Enterprise Service Management creates clean and streamlined experiences for support issues on invoices, disputes and other documents. With the ability to define case step pre-conditions based on values in these business documents case processes and flows can be automated to reflect business document updates.  As an example, if an invoice status changes to 'posted' then a related case can be set to 'closed' automatically without further support.

WalkMe In-App Help

WalkMe is an AI-powered digital adoption platform integrated across SAP Cloud ERP applications and is now integrated with SAP Enterprise Service Management. WalkMe not only accelerates onboarding and new agent training, it enables intuitive, in-app guidance for support agents on-demand. With WalkMe, teams can create step-by-step walkthroughs and contextual tips directly within the application. Additionally, WalkMe provides visibility into where agents encounter friction‚Äîhelping organizations continuously optimize their service processes.

Form Attachments

An enhancement to the existing dynamic forms capability enables form-based inquiry to include processes-specific documents. Employees or other users can upload relevant documents during request submission reducing follow-ups or additional cycles to gather missing information. As per the case type, the intake form can be defined to designate specific attachments as required reducing errors and reducing risk, especially valuable with  case flows for audits and compliance regulations.

Additional

Use the SAP Enterprise Service Management managed tag when posting on SAP ESM topics! And thank you for your active participation in the community. We all benefit from hearing about successes and challenges with SAP Enterprise Service Management and how you‚Äôre using the solution. 

If you feel you have missed some innovations ‚Äì check the What‚Äôs New ‚Äì and filter by a date range to see all the innovations and improvements  delivered. Never miss an innovation!

entry.title: Re: SAP Business One Service Layer ‚Äì Copy From Landed Cos...
entry.content: Thanks for confirming. This is an important Service Layer limitation to be aware of ‚Äî Landed Cost ‚Üí A/P Invoice linkage is only supported via GUI, not DI API or Service Layer. For automation, teams typically accept no relationship map or use a hybrid GUI/RPA approach for this step.

entry.title: Re: Why SAP B1 Landed Cost Distribution Rule not copy ove...
entry.content:
This is standard SAP B1 behavior.

  1. Yes ‚Äî when you copy Landed Cost to A/P Invoice, the document becomes Service type by design.

  2. Distribution Rules are not carried over from Landed Cost to the broker A/P Invoice. SAP does not map cost center/distribution rules in this copy process.

  3. Same behavior applies even with a single line ‚Äî it‚Äôs a system limitation, not a configuration issue.

Distribution Rules must be manually maintained on the A/P Invoice or handled via customization/add-on if required.

entry.title: Re: Issue in Printing 7 Copies of Invoice ‚Äì Item Table No...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is a known limitation of Adobe Forms + Output Management.

Root cause:

  • Tables (item loops) cannot be placed inside a repeating subform that itself repeats the whole invoice.

  • This is why the item table renders only once and Adobe throws errors when nested in the repeat layout.

Correct approach:

  • Create one main repeating subform (7 occurrences).

  • Inside it, place: Header + Item table + Totals.

  • Set the item table to flow and repeat per data, not per layout.

  • Do not nest repeating tables inside another repeating container.

Copy labels:

  • Use the occurrence index ($.index / instanceIndex) of the repeating subform.

  • Drive labels via conditional text, e.g.:

    • 1 = Original

    • 2 = Duplicate

    • 3 = Triplicate

    • 4‚Äì7 = Extra Copy

This is the only supported pattern in Public Cloud since print parameters (number of copies) are not available.

entry.title: Re: eDoc Cockpit - Connection to partner timed o ut after...
entry.content:
This is a known limitation in eDocument Cockpit / DRC when handling large attachments.

The 600s timeout comes from the ICF / ICM / SOAP runtime, not from the eDocument framework itself. Increasing icm/server_port_* timeout may help technically, but it is not the recommended solution.

Recommended approaches:

Avoid sending very large attachments (30MB is high for synchronous SOAP).

Store the document in ArchiveLink / external repository and send a reference or hash instead of the full binary.

If supported by the partner, switch to asynchronous processing rather than synchronous SOAP.

Extending timeouts only masks the issue and may impact system stability

entry.title: Re: FREIGHT COST (Planned Delivery costs)
entry.content: In standard S/4HANA Public Cloud, planned delivery costs are PO‚Äëheader based and allow only one freight vendor. For multiple freight vendors per partial delivery, SAP‚Äërecommended approaches are unplanned delivery costs at MIRO or separate service POs per shipment. Changing freight vendor per GR is not supported without customization.

entry.title: Re: Overhead Cost Calculation on WBS ‚Äì No Results Generated
entry.content: If the same cost elements are already in the costing sheet base, please also check: ‚Ä¢ WBS has Overhead Key assigned (Project/WBS master) ‚Ä¢ Cost elements are primary (category 1) and non‚Äëstatistical ‚Ä¢ Costs are posted directly to the WBS (not via cost center settlement) ‚Ä¢ Costing sheet validity dates, controlling area, and version match the run In Public Cloud, missing Overhead Key on WBS is the most common reason for ‚Äúsuccessful run with zero results‚Äù.

entry.title: Re: Auto-download Documents
entry.content:
This is not possible via configuration in SAP Service and Asset Manager.
Attachments are downloaded on‚Äëdemand only to avoid performance and storage issues.
Showing ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúDownload‚Äù requires a custom extension (MDK/client‚Äëside customization).

entry.title: Re: Question: Delivery-cost condition error during Servic...
entry.content: This is by design. Delivery cost condition types are meant for material logistics (GR/freight) and are not relevant for service POs / SES. If the same pricing schema is used for both materials and services, SAP will still validate the condition during SES and may raise errors. Best practice is to use a separate calculation schema for service POs or exclude delivery‚Äëcost condition types from service scenarios.

entry.title: Re: Harmonised System codes from catalogue item in Guided Buying
entry.content: In standalone SAP Ariba Buying, HS codes from supplier catalogs are not supported as a standard visible/reportable field at requisition line level. The requisition shows the commodity code (UNSPSC / ERP mapping) only. HS codes can exist in the catalog but are not exposed by default.

entry.title: Re: Storing of documents in database table
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition there is no official support for storing attachments temporarily in custom tables (RAWSTRING/BLOB), even as an interim step.

The recommended pattern is to create a draft or preliminary business object early (for example using RAP draft handling or a lightweight ‚Äúrequest‚Äù BO) and attach documents to it using the standard Attachment APIs. Upon approval, this BO is either finalized or transformed into the final contract object.

References you can look into:
‚Ä¢ RAP Draft Handling concept (Draft BOs before final save)
‚Ä¢ Attachment Service for Business Objects (API_ATTACHMENT_SRV)
‚Ä¢ Extensibility guidelines: ‚ÄúDo not store large binaries in custom tables in Public Cloud‚Äù

This avoids database growth, audit issues, and upgrade risks.

entry.title: Business ByDesign: Migration Guide - SAP Intelligent RPA to SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
Migration Guide: SAP Intelligent RPA to SAP Build Process Automation

As SAP transitions from Intelligent Robotic Process Automation (IRPA) to SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA), customers need a clear roadmap for a smooth migration. This guide outlines essential pre- and post-migration activities to ensure success.

Planned Timeline: The migration is scheduled to take place between 23rd January and 26th January to ensure minimal disruption.

Pre-Migration Activities: Customer Checklist

Environment Readiness

To ensure a smooth migration, it is recommended to:

  • Use the latest SDK versions from Cloud Factory
  • Prefer Desktop Agent 3.x for stability (available in Cloud Factory)
  • Clean up unused automation artifacts:
  • Remove outdated projects
  • Undeploy unused versions
  • Delete obsolete triggers

Suspend All Automation Activities Before Migration

Before triggering migration, ensure:

  • Stop all scheduled jobs
  • Ensure no attended or unattended bot is running
  • Disable all triggers
  • Allow in-progress jobs to complete or cancel them

This prevents execution conflicts during tenant transformation.

Note: After successful completion of migration, you can resume all active jobs.

Post-Migration Activities: Customer Checklist

1. How to confirm migration completion?

Step 1: Log in to SAP ByDesign and navigate to Business Configuration ‚Üí Implementation/Change Project ‚Üí Edit ‚Üí Select the Scoping Question under Integration with External Applications and Solutions ‚Üí Integration Scenarios for Cloud Solutions from SAP. Both SAP Build Process Automation and IRPA should be scoped.

Additional confirmation (optional): Navigate to Service Control ‚Üí Service Request. Look for Request ID - BYD_ML_SPA created during migration.

Step 2: Application and User Management ‚Üí Input and Output Management ‚Üí Communication Arrangements. Search for the BPA application and verify the Service URL.

2. Validate BPA Cloud Factory

Ensure all IRPA artifacts have migrated to BPA:

  • Confirm all bots, workflows, and triggers appear in BPA
  • Validate using the Monitor tab
  • Re-enable schedules and triggers
  • Validate agent connectivity

3. Descope IRPA after successful validation

If migration is confirmed, manually descope IRPA for each tenant:

Business Configuration ‚Üí Implementation Project ‚Üí Edit ‚Üí Select the Scoping Question under Integration with External Applications and Solutions ‚Üí Integration Scenarios for Cloud Solutions from SAP. Remove IRPA and click Next ‚Üí Finish.

Note: If the implementation Project is closed, then the customer can perform descoping of IRPA using a change project.

Important: Without descoping IRPA, BPA cannot be actively used.

4. What if issues occur?

Raise a case to SAP support. If migration issues require rollback, IRPA will remain active until resolved. Do NOT descope IRPA if issues are found.

Additional references:


https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/business-bydesign-migration-from-sap-intelligent-rpa-to-sap-build-process/ba-p/14271585

entry.title: Is there a way to export site launchpad config from BTP NEO in an Excel Spreadsheet
entry.content:
With the SAP BTP NEO sunset, we are working on migration Project of Launchpad from NEO to cloud foundary &/ Workzone.

In neo we have Role-->Catalog-->App relationship and some 500 (Apps, catalogs & Roles) objects with 1200 references.

Where as in Workzone the relation ship is Role to App or spaces& pages,

Though the site is migrated and imported into workzone, the previous relationship of objects differ and so we need to consolidate roles --> Apps & Roles to Catalog.

Is there a way to export NEO site's config in an excel spreadsheet, for easy reference & look up?

I couldn't find a out of box solution.

Thank you,
Sai

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to export site launchpad config from B...
entry.content:
I drafted a script as below, open configuration cockpit, then open browser developer tools, and in console run the below script.
It will read all config (Role, Catalog & App info) and produces an excel spreadsheet for download.

Hope this helps for someone looking to consolidate LPD config.

let aExportList = [];
var getDateAsString = (sDate)=>{
    sDate = sDate || new Date();
    let day = sDate.getDate();
    let monthIndex = sDate.getMonth();
    let year = sDate.getFullYear();
    let monthNames = ["Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", "Aug","Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"];
    let month = monthNames[monthIndex];
    return `${day}-${month }-${year}`;
}
// Prepare url for ajax call
var getURL = (sId)=>{
    let sUrl = "",
    searchParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search),
    sSiteId = searchParams.get("siteId"),
    sDomain = $(location).attr("origin");
    sUrl = sDomain+"/fiori/api/v3/cdm/apps?siteId="+sSiteId+"&catalogId="+sId;
    return sUrl;
}
//Get header title
var getHeaderTitle = ()=>{
  let oShell, oHeaderBar, oHeader, sTitle;
  oShell = sap.ui.getCore().byId("shellPage");
  oHeaderBar = oShell ? oShell.getContent()[0].getHeader() : null;
  oHeader = oHeaderBar ? oHeaderBar.getContent().filter(a=>{return a.aCustomStyleClasses.includes("headerTitle");})[0] : null;
  sTitle = oHeader ? oHeader.getText() : "Cloud Extract";
  return sTitle.replace(/ /g, "_");
}
var triggerCatalogsLoad = () =>{
    return new Promise(function(resolve, reject){
        let oSidePanel, oContentMgmt, oSideCatalogsTab
        oSidePanel = sap.ui.getCore().byId("adminRendererSideNavigation");
        oContentMgmt = oSidePanel ? oSidePanel.getItem().getItems().filter(a=>{ return a.getText() === "Content Management";})[0] : null;
        if (oContentMgmt){
          oContentMgmt.expand();
          oSideCatalogsTab = oContentMgmt.getItems().filter(a=>{return a.getText() === "Catalogues";})[0];
          if(oSideCatalogsTab) {oSideCatalogsTab.fireSelect();}
          setTimeout(() => {resolve(true);}, 1000);
        } else{
            reject(false);
        }
    });
};
var getApps = () =>{
    return new Promise(function(resolve, reject){
        let sId = $(".sapMSplitContainerMaster").attr("id"),
            aAppsList = [],
            oMaster = sap.ui.getCore().byId(sId),
            oCatalogsListControl = oMaster.getPages()[0].getController().getListControl(),
            sLength = oCatalogsListControl.getModel().oData.items.length,
            sCount = 0;
        if(oCatalogsListControl){
            oCatalogsListControl.getModel().oData.items.forEach((sRec,index)=>{
                $.ajax({
                    type: "GET",
                    url: getURL(sRec.id),
                    dataType: "json"
                }).done(function(result){
                    var sData = {"CatalogId":"","CatalogTitle":"", "CreatedBy": "", "Createdon": "", "ChangedBy": "", "ChangedOn":"", "Roles":[],"Apps":[]};
                    var dFormat =(d)=>{var b = new Date(d); return b.toLocaleDateString('en-GB');};
                    sData.CatalogId = sRec.id;
                    sData.CatalogDesc = sRec.description;
                    sData.CatalogTitle = sRec.title;
                    sData.CreatedBy= sRec.createdBy;
                    sData.Createdon= dFormat(sRec.createdOn);
                    sData.ChangedBy= sRec.updatedBy;
                    sData.ChangedOn= dFormat(sRec.updatedOn);
                    
                    if(sRec.assignedRoles){
                        sRec.assignedRoles.forEach(sRole=>{
                            sData.Roles.push({Roleid:sRole.id, RoleTitle:sRole.title});
                        });
                    }
                    if(result && result.applications && result.applications.length > 0){
                        result.applications.forEach(sApp=>{
                            if(sApp.cdm.texts){
                                for (var key in sApp.cdm.texts) {
                                    if(key.includes("title")){
                                        sData.Apps.push({Title:sApp.cdm.texts[key].value[""],"AppId": sApp.cdm["sap.app"].id});
                                        break;
                                    }
                                }
                            }
                        });
                    }
                    aAppsList.push(sData);
                    sCount++;
                    if(sCount === sLength){
                        resolve(aAppsList);
                    }
                })
            });
            
        } else{
            reject([]);
        }
    });
};
var getExportList = (aAppsList) =>{
    aAppsList.forEach(a=>{
        var bRec = {
            "Catalog ID": a.CatalogId,
            "Catalog Description":  a.CatalogDesc,
            "Catalog Title": a.CatalogTitle,
            "Created By": a.CreatedBy,
            "Created On": a.Createdon,
            "Changed By":  a.ChangedBy,
            "Changed On": a.ChangedOn,
            "App ID":"",
            "App Title":"",
            "Role ID":"",
            "Role Title":""
        };
        if(a.Apps.length > 0){
            a.Apps.forEach(b=>{
                if(a.Roles.length > 0) {
                    a.Roles.forEach(r=>{
                    var cRec = {};
                    jQuery.extend(true,cRec ,bRec);
                        cRec ["App ID"] = b.AppId;
                        cRec ["App Title"] = b.Title;
                        cRec ["Role ID"] = r.Roleid;
                        cRec ["Role Title"] = r.RoleTitle;
                        aExportList.push(cRec );
                    });
                } else{
                
                    var cRec = {};
                    jQuery.extend(true,cRec ,bRec);
                    cRec ["App ID"] = b.AppId;
                    cRec ["App Title"] = b.Title;
                    aExportList.push(cRec );
                }
            });
        } else {
            if(a.Roles.length > 0) {
                a.Roles.forEach(r=>{
                    var cRec = {};
                    jQuery.extend(true,cRec ,bRec);
                    cRec ["Role ID"] = r.Roleid;
                    cRec ["Role Title"] = r.RoleTitle;
                    aExportList.push(cRec );
                });
            } else {
                aExportList.push(bRec);
            }
        }
    });
};
downloadExcel = () =>{
    $.getScript("https://cdn.sheetjs.com/xlsx-0.20.1/package/dist/xlsx.full.min.js", (data, textStatus, jqxhr)=>{
        if(jqxhr.status  === 200){
            triggerCatalogsLoad()
            .then((res1)=>{
                if(res1){
                    getApps()
                    .then((res2)=>{
                        if(res2){
                            getExportList(res2);
                            const worksheet = XLSX.utils.json_to_sheet(aExportList);
                            if(!worksheet["!cols"]) worksheet["!cols"] = [];
                            for(var i = 0; i <= 12; ++i) {
                                if(!worksheet["!cols"][i]) worksheet["!cols"][i] = {wch: 50};
                              }
                            const workbook = XLSX.utils.book_new();
                            let sFileName = getHeaderTitle()+"_"+getDateAsString();
                            XLSX.utils.book_append_sheet(workbook, worksheet, "Exported_on_"+getDateAsString());
                            XLSX.writeFile(workbook, sFileName+".xlsx", { compression: true, cellStyles: true });
                        }else{
                            alert("failed to read catalogs data");
                        }
                    })
                } else{
                    alert("failed to load catalogs");
                }
            });
        } else {
            alert("failed to load excel api");
        }
    });
}
downloadExcel();

entry.title: TM Scheduling of Sales / Purchasing / Delivery Documents with BPS Integration
entry.content:
Dear friends of TM,

With S/4HANA 2023 FPS01, we released the long-awaited TM based Sales Order Scheduling for embedded TM in a first version for the determination of durations for transport-relevant activities. Following that, we already planned a more complex but also more accurate determination of dates and times for transport-relevant activities, which we published with S/4HANA 2023 FPS02.

But at this time, we couldn‚Äôt imagine that this was just the beginning of a journey. And you, the customers, the partners and also many colleagues made this happen with your valuable feedback which motivated us to push this topic further.

As of now, we have enabled the TM based scheduling for five (!) business documents, enhanced the functionality and also spent some BAdIs to enable customers to make modification-free enhancements.

It‚Äôs surely time to provide an overview of the current functionality!

Overview

The following is the general architecture for our TM scheduling:

 

  1. The requested delivery date from the business document is the input for the Business Process Scheduling (BPS), where the calculation of the relevant dates is managed.
  2. Based on the requested delivery date, Transportation Management (TM) can calculate durations or dates/times for the activities loading, transport and unloading by backward scheduling, ending up in a requested picking date. From that, BPS calculates a requested material availability date as input for Available-to-Promise (ATP).
  3. ATP confirms a material availability date of the product from which BPS calculates the respective confirmed picking date.
  4. If this confirmed picking date differs from the requested picking date, TM calculates the confirmed delivery date with forward scheduling. Otherwise, the requested delivery date becomes the confirmed delivery date.

When a business document is integrated with BPS, basically two options are possible:

  • BPS Determination: Durations of defined activities are retrieved. When TM is the source for this retrieval, this can be done with the default route, with straight line distances and durations and with the functionality of the network path determination.
  • BPS Delegation: Dates and times of defined activities are retrieved. Regarding TM, the same means as for the BPS Determination are possible and additionally schedule departures can be considered.
Business Documents

With that, the following business documents are enabled to be integrated with BPS and TM as described before:

Customer Enhancements

As already mentioned, we thankfully received a tremendous amount of feedback. One thing that showed up very early was the fact that customers need more flexibility.

Therefore, we invested in the following BadIs:

During creation of the business document (in the respective transaction, before saving), the Scheduling Handler in TM receives the scheduling request from BPS and compiles it for TRS. This is a new API within TM, designed for the TM scheduling functionality, using existing functions of transportation planning. And when TRS has derived durations or dates/times, those are sent back to BPS. The goal is, to have as much similarities to the transportation planning after logistics integration (means when the business document is finally created and persisted) as possible.

In the Scheduling Handler, BAdI /SCMTMS/BADI_LI_TRS_BTD_CHG has been introduced with a note and offers the following two enhancement options:

  • At the beginning of the Scheduling Handler, the input data from the business document can be adjusted. This method has the same interface as BAdI /SCMTMS/BADI_LI_BTD_CHG where business document data at the beginning of logistics integration can be adjusted. This enables customers to use a similar enhancement logic for logistics integration and TM scheduling.
  • Before calling TRS, the respective input data can also be adjusted. 
Further Information

We have collected some of the frequently asked questions in this note.

There's also a note for the support of scheduling agreements and another note for the support of outbound deliveries.

Please, also follow those links in the help portal:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/94b155b3c1524164add6b448dc3186dc.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/69fc86c287fe44ff8033efe4e66743d7.html

Best regards,

Michael

entry.title: AMS instance-based (row-level) filtering not applied in CAP using dynamic user attributes
entry.content:
Issue: AMS instance-based filtering not working as expected in CAP
We are using AMS to implement row-level (instance-based) filtering in a CAP service. Below is a minimal reproducible example.

Schema
 
SCHEMA {
Supplier: String,
$user: {
supplierid: String
}
}
 
AMS Policy

POLICY ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER { GRANT read ON FPOReview WHERE Supplier = $user.supplierid; }

Service & Entity

service FPOService @(path: '/fpo-service')
{ entity FPOReview as projection on my.FPOReview { Supplier, * };
annotate FPOReview with @AMS.attributes: { Supplier: (Supplier) };
}
 
User Token (excerpt)
 
{ "supplierid": "17008974" }

Observed Behavior
When the user is assigned to policy ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER in IAS, the service returns all rows, instead of filtering records where Supplier = 17008974.
When we add @requires: ['ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER'] on the service or entity, the request starts failing with 403 Forbidden.

Questions
1. Is AMS expected to automatically apply row-level filtering based on @AMS.attributes and the policy condition (Supplier = $user.supplierid)?

2. Should assigning the policy alone be sufficient to filter records, or is @requires mandatory‚Äîand if so, why does it result in 403 Forbidden

Our requirement is to restrict data so that users only see records for suppliers assigned to them. While we can implement this manually in JavaScript handlers, we want to understand how AMS can be utilised for this use case, especially around dynamic attributes.

We are using a custom schema defined in IAS to obtain the supplier ID list. To simplify the initial testing and verify that dynamic attributes are working correctly, we have temporarily added a simple string attribute supplierid to the custom schema. We are able to successfully retrieve this value in our CAP application, but policies are not working.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Test Automation Tool in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition CE2602
entry.content:
Introduction 

As we continue to innovate and enhance the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool (TAT), the CE2602 release brings powerful new capabilities designed to make post-upgrade testing smarter, faster, and more efficient. In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through the latest features delivered with CE2602, including advanced comparison options in the Post Upgrade Test (PUT) App, enhanced TDC AutoBind integration, and a new capability in i-TS for Smart Execution. These improvements aim to simplify test management, expand coverage, and reduce manual effort‚Äîhelping you achieve greater accuracy and productivity in your testing workflows.

Full Scope Comparison (PUT application)

The Full Scope Comparison feature provides a holistic view of two PUT executions (Standard & Custom) across different releases or runs.

  • Comprehensive Analysis: Compare two complete PUT executions for detailed insights.
  • Side-by-Side Summary: View execution details, triggers, and timestamps for quick reference.
  • Impact Identification: Rapidly detect post-upgrade changes across the entire PUT landscape for thorough validation and risk mitigation.

Fig.1 : Execution comparator showcasing the comparison feature of two test runs

Comparison of Custom Automates (PUT application)

This feature enables detailed analysis of custom automated test plans across different PUT runs.

  • Cross-Run Comparison: Analyse custom PUT automated test plans executed in two different runs.
  • Instance-Level Status: Displays detailed status for each test plan, such as:
    • Success
    • Failed
    • Pre-checks Failed
    • Cancelled

Fig.2 : Showcases comparison support for customer test plans

Enhanced AutoBind for Test Data Container Integration

AutoBind logic has been significantly improved to make test setup faster and more accurate.

  • Intelligent Mapping: Maps Test Data Container (TDC) fields to script labels for both Standard & PUT automates.
  • Improved Accuracy: Ensures precise alignment between test data and scripts.
  • Reduced Manual Effort: Minimises manual intervention during test setup.

Fig. 3 : Showcases enhanced auto bind capability for TDC integration

Scoping Capability (PUT application)

The new Smart Execution feature enhances flexibility by allowing users to include i-TS recommended scope along with custom scope in custom variants.

  • Comprehensive Coverage: Combine i-TS recommended processes with standard and custom-defined processes while executing a custom variant for PUT.
  • Flexible Execution: Provides control to selectively merge scopes for a unified test run.
  • Improved Accuracy: Ensures critical i-TS recommended scenarios are validated alongside custom flows for reliable post-upgrade assessment.

Fig. 4 : Showcases capability to include i-TS recommended processes while executing a custom variant for PUT

Why It Matters

These updates significantly improve testing efficiency, enhance data accuracy, reduce manual setup effort, and boost overall productivity across all post-upgrade test automation workflows.

SAP Delivered Standard Automates

The total list of SAP delivered automated test scripts are 505 for 2602 release and can be accessed via link ‚Äì Automated Test Scripts Index‚Äù. This includes 26 new scope items which were added this release.

Further detailed change information about the standard automate is available in the ‚ÄúTest Script Release Change Information‚Äù.

Learn More: 

Important Links and Updates

We have created a new Learning Hub course for an overview of the tool. This is a good starting point for anyone who is new to the tool or want to get an overview of the new features we have added over the past couple of years. [Before you can access the link, a one-time registration in the SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, is required. A detailed step-by-step guidance can be found here]

 As part of our PUT 2.0 Enablement also we have created a set of short videos which cover the most important aspects of the process. The video playlist can be accessed here.

 Links to other important blogs:

  • How to get started with the Test Automation Tool for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

Please bookmark the test automation community page to keep up with the latest updates happening in the test automation space.

For more details on the functionality please refer the links below:

  • Post-Upgrade Tests App
  • Intelligent Test Scoper (i-TS) 
  • Manage Upgrade Tests 
  • Manage Your Test Processes
  • Test Your Processes
  • Test Data Container
  • Analyze Automated Test Results
  • Configure Conditional Authentication
  • Also refer FAQs

Questions, feedback, or tips? Comment below or connect with us on SAP Community! Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts.

Follow us on @SAP and #S4HANA, and myself on LinkedIn.

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud: Q4 2025 Innovation Highlights
entry.content:
SAP Sales Cloud: Q4 2025 Innovation Highlights

With a robust set of AI-first innovations already delivered throughout 2025, SAP Sales Cloud‚Äôs Q4 update continues to expand intelligent capabilities, flexibility, extensibility, and key workflow enhancements to maximize sales productivity. This blog will cover a few key feature highlights that are worth a closer look. For a more in-depth showcase on these capabilities and more, we invite you to register for the SAP Sales Cloud Innovation and Foundation webcast on Wednesday, January 28th. Register today to stay on top of new innovations and enhancements, as well as exciting details on our 2026 solution roadmap.

Additional innovation resources: SAP CX Portfolio    l    SAP Service Cloud and ESM

What‚Äôs New in SAP Sales Cloud

Naturally 2025 was a year of enhancing and embedding agentic AI capabilities within SAP Sales Cloud and the extended lead-to-cash value chain, but we also released a significant number of enhancements around ease of use, specific customer requests, quality-of-life improvements for admins, Joule for B2B sales, and developments designed to further streamline sales processes with deep integration and infused AI. Additionally, the AI agent builder continues to be enhanced so users can easily create and deploy agentic B2B sales use cases in clicks. With so many exciting new features and enhancements we can‚Äôt cover them all here‚Ä¶ so without further ado, here are four highlights from our Q4 2025 SAP Sales Cloud release to dig into.   

AI-enhanced Quote Generation

Opportunities are constantly changing as deals progress, especially in complex deal cycles with detailed configuration or changing requirements. SAP Sales Cloud‚Äôs AI-enhanced Quote Generation helps remove guesswork and reduces manual effort by automatically creating draft quotes. The solution‚Äôs quotation AI agent works in the background, reading and analyzing rich data and email content for key information. From the data analysis, Sales Cloud extracts customer intent and intended product line items, automatically creating a draft quote for the appropriate opportunity. Commonly referred to as ‚ÄúAI ‚Äì Email to Quote‚Äù, this feature replaces manual configuration and helps sales organizations shorten response times. Sellers are then free to quickly review, augment if needed, and send the quote without being bogged down in complexity.

SAP Sales Cloud + Microsoft Teams: Chat Experience

Our existing release of SAP Sales Cloud already included deep integration with Microsoft Teams, but our Q4 2025 release greatly expanded this experience with embedded Chat. Now users can Teams Chat directly within SAP Sales Cloud. Peer-to-peer, meeting follow up, or group chats are seamlessly supported so users can start, view, and continue key conversations without leaving Sales Cloud. This enhancement helps users stay connected, faster without losing context or needing to switch between applications. Customer-related communication is tied to the relevant CRM data so users can engage, collaborate, and progress deals quickly.

AI Duplicate Check Enhancement

Legacy CRM systems often have notoriously bad or duplicate data for a variety of reasons, but we are determined to make this issue a thing of the past. SAP Sales Cloud follows clean core development principles and our vision for data quality and orchestration is an extension of this mindset. As we look to the future of B2B sales, AI is and will play a critical role, but AI is only as good as the data it consumes. AI Duplicate Check within Sales Cloud uses embedded intelligence to uncover loose, partial, and soft match duplicates so users can easily unite and clean records to improve quality with little effort. Our Q4 2025 update strengthens these capabilities and has been optimized to help sellers with lead flow. Once a seller has qualified a lead and is ready to move the prospect into an opportunity cycle, AI Duplicate Check reviews CRM data and guides the user to link the lead / converted opportunity to the appropriate account or CRM records. This feature can dramatically simplify lead conversion while improving user experience and data quality.

Subscription Contracts and Renewals

With ongoing market disruption and quickly evolving industry trends, flexible business models and dynamic solution offerings continue to rise in popularity. In this regard we have enhanced SAP Sales Cloud‚Äôs ability to better support subscription offerings with high complexity through a deep integration with SAP CPQ. Now users can easily create subscription contracts or solution renewals for complex offerings from an opportunity with just a few clicks. The streamlined integration unites Sales Cloud, CPQ, and SAP Cloud ERP, providing a consistent subscription flow from opportunity, to quote, to order, and contract. Once fulfilled account and opportunity records automatically synchronize, providing a clear and consistent source of truth.

Ready for more?

We‚Äôre very excited to showcase these and more highlights on the SAP Sales Cloud Innovation and Foundation webcast on Wednesday, January 28th. In addition to a deeper dive and solution demonstration of these features, we will also share upcoming roadmap items and answer questions in real-time. To dive deeper into specific use cases or for a personalize showcase drop us a note on SAP.com.

entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event comprised of 2 parts.

1. Getting Started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core with Python. You do not need any background in the topic, but you should have a lot of curiosity! Here you will learn how to use the Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). This approach improves the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduces hallucinations. You will learn how to deploy an LLM and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core, and how to query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Additionally, you will gain insights into key generative AI concepts and learn how to enhance RAG responses.

2. Introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

Prerequisites

entry.title: Don't Let Your Integration Take a Coffee Break: Client Certificate Changes In 2026!
entry.content:
Introduction

If integrations were people, you‚Äôd dread them slipping out for coffee breaks just when you need them most. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Integrated Business Planning (IBP), and SAP Marketing Cloud (SMC) are all about to experience an important update to how client certificates are issued. This change, prompted by evolving industry standards, involves a change of the Certificate Authority (CA) for the Default Client certificate. It‚Äôs important to note that this CA change has the potential to cause one of those dreaded coffee breaks‚Äîdisruptions in connectivity‚Äîif not handled properly.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening, who should pay attention, and how to keep your setup on track.

Who Is Affected?

If you use the Client Default certificate for outbound authentication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, IBP, or SMC, this change applies to you. Anyone relying on these certificates for outbound integrations should pay attention, as missing the update could lead to disruptions in communication.

This only applies to customer managed integration scenarios. SAP managed ones will be taken care of by SAP, of course.

What Is Changing?

Currently, the Default Client certificates for outbound communication are issued by DigiCert. In February 2026, SAP Cloud Root CA becomes the new certificate authority for newly issued client certificates. You‚Äôll also notice updates to certificate subject names, including additional organizational fields. These changes will be present in all new client certificates issued during routine rotation.

To help visualize the upcoming changes, here‚Äôs a quick comparison of the old and new default client certificates:

Certificate Attribute

Old (Before Rotation)

New (After Rotation)

Subject

CN=<your tenant hostname>

CN=<your tenant hostname>
OU=<some UID>

Issuer

DigiCert Global G2

SAP Cloud Root CA

Extended Key Usage

Client Authentication,
Server Authentication

Client Authentication

The new OU value is specific to the product (S/4/IBP/ SMC) and will remain the same during future certificate rotations.

Timeline and Notification: When and How Will You be Informed?

New systems will receive client certificates signed by SAP Cloud Root CA starting late March 2026. Existing systems will begin renewal with a staging certificate from late February 2026, fully transitioning during their next scheduled key rotation. In case you wonder: the fact that these dates are close to the 2602 release is a pure coincidence. System upgrades and certificate changes are separate processes.
The rotation schedule and rotation process do not change. There will be no additional certificate rotation.

Example: if your current Client Default certificate is valid until April 2026, the CA change will happen in April for you. If your certificate expires in November, you‚Äôll keep your DigiCert certificate until November and then switch to SAP Cloud Root CA.

The usual notification email about certificate rotation will include additional details about the change in Certificate Authority. Please review it carefully to ensure you understand the updates and can take the right actions in response. The process for certificate rotation is described on this help page.

Potential Issues and Required Action

For clarity, we'll refer to the system, tenant, service, or device that receives and validates connections from your SAP cloud tenant (S/4 cloud, IBP, SMC) as the target environment. Such target environments could be anything from BTP apps, SAP solutions like SAP Ariba or SAP SuccessFactors, third-party products running in the cloud or on-premises, or even custom-built applications.

How Things Might Break

Misalignment of configurations in your SAP cloud tenant and the target environment can lead to two categories of issues:

  • CA Trust Failures: If your target environment does not trust the SAP Cloud Root CA, it will reject the new certificate. In these cases, the mutual TLS (mTLS) handshake fails, and communication is blocked at the TLS layer. No HTTP error code is returned.
  • User / System / Identity Mapping Errors: in the target environment, the certificate metadata (subject, issuer) is mapped to the identity of a user or process. Consequently, if the mapping is not changed to use the new subject and issuer, authorization errors (such as HTTP 403 or 401) will happen. Depending on the implementation of the target environment, TLS errors could also occur.

Technical Aside: Certificate Pinning vs CA Trust

For certificate-based authentication, most target environments will rely on CA trust, where the target environment validates the certificate‚Äôs chain up to a trusted root CA. With the switch to SAP Cloud Root CA, you must add this CA to the trust store in the target environment and check your user mapping logic.

For environments using certificate pinning, simply upload the new certificate when the rotation occurs. In this case, the certificate is identified by the fingerprint of the certificate‚Äôs key rather than the metadata of the certificate (i.e. subject and issuer). Target environments using certificate pinning must be updated every time the certificate rotates ‚Äì the CA change does not make a difference here.

Required Actions for Customers

To maintain uninterrupted integrations, customers using the Client Default certificate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, IBP, and SMC should:

  1. Update CA Trust: Make sure the SAP Cloud Root CA is trusted by your target environment. You can download the root certificate from the SAP Trust Center.
  2. Adjust User/System/Identity Mapping: Update your mapping logic to recognize the new certificate subject and issuer, ensuring the target environment properly identifies and authorizes the incoming connection.

More information on the topic is available in SAP note 3677763 as well as the relevant help pages:

  • How to Handle Default Client Certificate Renewal
  • Set Up Certificate-to-User Mapping (SAP Cloud Integration and SAP Marketing Cloud)
  • Client Certificate Authentication for Integration Flow Processing (SAP Integration Suite)
  • Client Certificate Authentication for API Clients (SAP Integration Suite)

Conclusion

While this certificate update might seem like an invitation for your integrations to sneak away for a coffee break, staying alert and updating your trust stores and mappings in your target environment will keep everything running without interruption. Pay attention to notification emails‚Äîso your integrations never miss a beat (or a sip).

entry.title: Hierarchy with Directory in SAP Datasphere ‚Äì Description vs. ID shown inconsistently across folders
entry.content:
Hello SAP Datasphere Community,

I am currently facing an issue with hierarchies created in SAP Datasphere, and I would like to understand whether this is a known behavior or a modeling issue on my side.

I created a product hierarchy with directory using a SQL View. The hierarchy is based on a remote table and exposed into Datasphere via a SQL View. The implementation follows exactly the approach described in the official SAP Community blog post ‚ÄúModeling a basic hierarchy with directory in SAP Datasphere‚Äù. Overall, the setup works as expected: the hierarchy is created correctly, all levels are visible, and it can be used in an Analytic Model. Descriptions are maintained and initially displayed correctly.

However, I am experiencing a problem when reusing the same hierarchy with directory in a different folder. In this case, the hierarchy is still visible and structurally correct in the Analytic Model, but when switching the display setting from ID to Description, the system continues to show the ID instead of the description. This happens even though the descriptions are clearly maintained and work correctly when the hierarchy is used in its original folder.

What makes this behavior particularly confusing is that my modeling approach is always identical, yet the outcome differs. When the hierarchy is used directly on top of the SQL View without persistence, the descriptions are displayed correctly. As soon as the SQL View is persisted, the hierarchy still works structurally, but only IDs are shown and the descriptions are no longer respected in the Analytic Model. The same inconsistency can also be observed when reusing the identical hierarchy definition in a different folder. In some cases, descriptions are displayed correctly, while in others only IDs appear. This inconsistent behavior makes it difficult to identify a clear root cause, as the same hierarchy definition behaves differently depending on persistence and folder context.

Hierarchies coming from BW are currently not an option. The issue occurs repeatedly across multiple hierarchies, not just a single one.

Has anyone experienced similar behavior with hierarchies and directories in SAP Datasphere? Are there known limitations or dependencies when reusing hierarchies across folders or when persisting SQL Views? Could this be related to metadata handling, caching, folder context, or semantic usage in Analytic Models? Any hints, explanations, or best practices to ensure that descriptions are consistently displayed instead of IDs would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Integrating SAP Customer Data Cloud with SAP Emarsys for personalized, compliant marketing
entry.content:
Connecting SAP Emarsys  with SAP Customer Data Cloud brings together two powerful capabilities: personalized, omnichannel marketing and privacy-first customer identity management. The integration creates a single, reliable view of each customer, combining identity, consent and profile data from the Customer Data Cloud with Emarsys‚Äô campaign orchestration and real-time engagement engine

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Why it matters (functionally)

  • Unified profiles: Customers‚Äô identity and preference data from the Customer Data Cloud flow into Emarsys so marketing teams work from consistent, up-to-date profiles.
  • Better segmentation and personalization: Rich attributes and consent signals enable more relevant audience segments and tailored messaging across channels.
  • Privacy and compliance by design: Consent and preference status managed in the Customer Data Cloud are honored in Emarsys campaigns, helping you meet privacy requirements while reducing manual checks.
  • Faster activation: Whether via real-time updates or scheduled syncs, customer changes are reflected quickly so campaigns stay aligned to current behavior and permissions.
  • Reduced data silos and simpler operations: Centralized identity management decreases duplication and cleanup work, freeing teams to focus on strategy and performance.

Practical steps (high level)

  • Establish the connector between platforms and authenticate access.
  • Map key attributes (identity, contact info, preferences, consent) from Customer Data Cloud to Emarsys fields.
  • Decide on sync cadence (real-time vs. batch) and test end-to-end flows.
  • Validate consent flows and ensure opt-ins/opt-outs are enforced in campaigns.
  • Monitor and iterate on segments and journeys to maximize engagement.

Outcome
The result is more trusted, personalized customer engagement that scales without sacrificing compliance. If you‚Äôre looking to improve campaign relevance and reduce manual identity work, this integration is a practical next step.

More info

Official product documentation

  • SAP Emarsys integration guide
  • SAP Customer Data Cloud integration guide

Suggested learning.sap.com resources and what to look for:

  • https://learning.sap.com/courses/getting-started-with-sap-emarsys 
  • Exploring SAP Customer Data Cloud Essentials 
  • Implementing Data Inputs and Integrations in SAP Emarsys

entry.title: Re: Pass DEV transport orders to the QAS queue
